Title:
Complete genome sequence and comparative genomic analyses of
the vancomycin-producing Amycolatopsis orientalis
Keywords:
Amycolatopsis orientalis, complete genome sequencing,
molecular taxonomic characteristics, vancomycin biosynthesis
Abstract:
Background: Amycolatopsis orientalis is the type species
of the genus and its industrial strain HCCB10007 derived from ATCC 43491
has been used for large-scale production of the vital antibiotic
vancomycin. However, up to date, neither complete genomic sequence of
this species nor systemic characterization of vancomycin biosynthesis
cluster has been reported. With the only whole genome sequence of
Amycolatopsis mediterranei available, additional complete genomes of
other species may facilitate the intra-generic comparative analysis of
the genus. Results: The complete genome of A. orientalis HCCB10007
consists of an 8,948,591-bp circular chromosome and a 33,499-bp
dissociated plasmid. Totally, 8,121 protein coding sequences are
predicted, and the species-specific genomic features of A. orientalis
are comparatively analyzed against that of A. mediterranei. Besides, the
common characteristics of Amycolatopsis genomes are revealed via intra-
and inter-generic comparative genomic analyses within the domain of
actinomycetes, and directly lead to the development of sequence-based
Amycolatopsis molecular chemotaxonomic characteristics (MCCs). The
chromosomal core/quasi-core and non-core configurations of the A.
orientalis and the A. mediterranei genome are reciprocally analyzed,
with respect to further understanding both the discriminable criteria
and the evolutionary implementation. In addition, 26 gene clusters
related to the secondary metabolism including a 64-kb vcm cluster for
the biosynthesis of vancomycin are identified in the genome. By
employing a customized PCR-targeting-based mutagenesis system along with
the biochemical identification of vancomycin variants produced by the
mutants, we not only experimentally characterized a halogenase, a
methyltransferase and two glycosyltransferases encoded in the vcm
cluster but also inferred the broad substrate spectra characteristics of
these modification enzymes. Conclusions: This study not only extended
the genetic knowledge of genus Amycolatopsis and the biochemical
knowledge of vcm-related post-assembly tailoring enzymes, but also
developed methodology useful for in vivo studies in A. orientalis, which
has been widely considered as a barrier in this field.
